column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0062] The card processor or card issue's logic in the card authorization network would determine if the security code received from the card matches the security code in the payment processor's or card issuer's authorization system 718.
#Text=If the security codes match, the transaction is authorized and the system approves the security code 720.
#Text=If the security code sent by the card was pulled from a stored list of security codes, a counter logic within the card and card processing network would increment by one value 722.
#Text=If the security codes do not match, the transaction is rejected 724.
#Text=[0063] A complication that arises in the implementation of a dynamically generated security code is how long the security code should remain valid.

#Text=If the security code window of validity is limited to several minutes, online and mail order phone transactions have a high probability of success while faxed transactions or transactions accomplished by mail will nearly always fail.

#Text=Thus, there needs to be a balance between decreasing the potential for fraud activity and optimizing the types of transactions so that the overwhelming majority of card holder transactions are approved.
#Text=This time window is best optimized for a validity window of one to two weeks.
#Text=The determination of the optimum time window is typically selected by the card issuer based on their statistical data for card usage and the level of fraud activity.
#Text=[0064] FIG. 8 is a block diagram of a simple display code sequence enabling the use of a dynamically generated security code.

#Text=Using a time based implementation methodology where the security code changes by itself based on a periodic clock event, eliminates the de-synchronization possibility based on inadvertent repeated selection of the touch sensitive control button.
#Text=When the card is initialized by the card issuer, the card and the backend processing system controlled by the payment processor are synchronized.
#Text=As added protection, a limited time drift window may be implemented to further reduce potential problems ensuring that the security codes are not out of synchronization.

#Text=Also, the addition of a time drift solution could eliminate the need for a card holder to select the touch sensitive control button on the card, since the security code could change itself automatically based on input from the internal clock.
#Text=The only limitation on this solution would be the battery life with the display always on.

#Text=[0065] A time based methodology for the generation of security codes typically requires the card to have an internal clock or wireless access to a time keeping system so that the generation of security codes are synchronized with the card issuer or payment processor.
#Text=As an alternative, the card could connect to the payment processor or a third party who maintains a clock for synchronization timing solutions.

#Text=With a sufficiently long period of time window to deal with transactions that require a longer period of time, e.g. faxed or mail transactions, one security code could be used for multiple transactions that may occur during this time period window.

#Text=[0066] For the time window, a solution is to have a card capable of generating a new security code that is valid during a periodic time window that is sufficiently large enough to overcome delays that may exist in transactions that require more time, e.g. fax and mail transactions.
#Text=A typical time window could be as short as one week or as long as one month.
#Text=In other words, a specific security code will be valid for a fixed period of time and the same security code will be displayed on the card.
#Text=When the time window expires the card will dynamically generate a new code or recall from memory the next security code from a list of security codes stored on the card.

#Text=As an alternative embodiment for storing a list of security codes on the card, this list may be stored in the cloud on the card issuer's servers or card processor's servers and called by wireless commands automatically sent from the card to these servers without the card holder knowing that these communication messages are being sent and received by the card.

#Text=However, a major limitation for such a wireless interface with the cloud is for card holders who may be attempting to conduct a transaction in a remote location where wireless connections are not possible thus when it is time for the card holder to conduct a transaction, no current security code is stored on the card.
